title: Monday, 6th March, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Morning

PM11:00am

Busy weekend for some people

PM11:01am

And quite a busy morning

11:01 am
PM11:01am

I'd said I'd give UBS's women thing a plug here

PM11:01am

But the video i was going to run here isnt embed-able

PM11:01am

So you'll have to click

11:01 am
PM11:01am

https://www.ubs.co...nspiringwomen.html

PM11:01am

Please click

PM11:02am

Give em a bit of traffic

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Keeps relations sweet etc

PM11:02am

And i'll give you a good chuck of UBS macro grey later

PM11:02am

UBS people need to eat -- like journalists

11:02 am
PM11:03am

Instead, image wise, you can have 10p

PM11:03am

PM11:03am

There you go

11:03 am
PM11:03am

That -- on Friday's prices -- is the premium attached to Standard Life's takeover of Aberdeen Asset Management

PM11:03am

Or merger

PM11:04am

Or how do we term this Bryce?

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Standard Life seemingly giving away a huge amount of value -- and power

PM11:04am

two-thirds / one-third merger

BE11:04am

We call it a nil-premium takeover with the intention of cutting lots of jobs, while saving one.

11:04 am
PM11:05am

Lots and lots of jobs

PM11:05am

Good overview here I thought from Jonathan Eley

PM11:05am

https://www.ft.com...-ace0-1ce02ef0def9

11:05 am
BE11:05am

(@Chopper: that rumour was made up. Complete tosh.)

BE11:05am

It's worth recapping here what Aberdeen shareholders get

BE11:06am

.... in addition to that shiny coin up there, which they'll get in paper rather than metal.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

It divides up 33% of the company via a ratio of 0.757 SL shares.

BE11:06am

They also get some certainty over the dividend, which was previously unavailable given Aberdeen AUM is bleeding like a stuck pig.

BE11:06am

They also get two chief executives!

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Martin Gilbert and Keith Skeoch are going to take it in turns to use the executive washroom.

PM11:07am

Supposedly works in investment banking. Not so sure in assest management

BE11:07am

Yup. You'll remember several fund managers have been quite critical of the co-CEO structure. Henderson/Janus made quite a big deal of it when announcing their rather less desperate looking deal.

11:07 am
BE11:08am

But! £200m cost synergies! as in 10% of the combined base!

BE11:08am

...which is on the high side of forecasts pre the announcement, though RBC thinks it might still be lowballed .....

BE11:08am

[W]e find this figure achievable and even conservative, and believe that the actual figure could be closer to £250MM-£300MM. It is expected that the full run-rate cost synergies will be achieved three years after completion.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Against one-off integration cash costs of ~£320m in aggregate.

BE11:09am

Now, perhaps I wasn't fully awake. But I'm sure I heard Gilbert on the radio this morning denying (our) reports that 1k jobs were at risk, and saying savings are largely on the revenue line not costs.

BE11:09am

Now, tell me where the revenue synergies are here?

11:09 am
BE11:09am

31% from simplifying and harmonising platforms

BE11:09am

16% from distribution overlap

PM11:09am

Aberdeen’s Mr Gilbert told BBC Radio Four there would be “some job losses” from the deal but he did not reveal details of the scale. He described the figure of 1,000 job cuts as “way, way exaggerated”

11:09 am
BE11:09am

12% from rationalisation of central functions

PM11:09am

You were fully awake

BE11:09am

...... and 42% from "removing areas of duplication in investment management capability"

11:09 am
BE11:10am

.... are any of these revenue synergies? Because they all look to be on the cost line.

BE11:10am

That's certainly how the sellside's reading it.

BE11:10am

This suggests to us that the bulk of cost synergies will come from reductions in investment management personnel.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

That's Citi.

BE11:10am

And this is Barclays.

BE11:10am

The combined workforce globally totals ~9,000. Both groups have significant proportions of that in Scotland with overlap, which could be eliminated to create the synergies. This could prove politically contentious for Scotland. That said, this merger would create a Scottish asset management national champion. Aberdeen maybe considered vulnerable given its outflows, and hence, a Scottish solution might be the preferred outcome of Scottish politicians.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Still, it looks quite close to done.

BE11:11am

Non-binding support from Mitsubishi (17%) and Lloyds (10%)

BE11:11am

Lloyds also agrees a stay on pulling assets from Aberdeen for six months post the merger completing, and will give 12 months notice.

11:11 am
PM11:11am

On the jobs front -- technology has got to be key. Sense that the asset management industry in general is in denial -- or has been

PM11:12am

And in the area of financial advice -- robots going to do everything, for anyone worth less than $$$$$$

BE11:13am

Yep, this is the underbelly of the tracker fund argument ......

11:13 am
BE11:13am

..... you really don't need a lot of actual humans to run or market a tracker.

BE11:13am

And in that context the positives of this deal are predicated on Aberdeen and, to a lesser extent Standard Life Asset Management, being in terminal decline.

BE11:14am

Which might well be correct, but it's not the image they're wanting to project.

11:14 am
PM11:14am

I put a bit Morgan Stanley thing on robo-advice up in the LR a little while back

PM11:14am

Have a read of that https://ftalphavil...room/content/71020

BE11:15am

..... because who wants to lead your employees a defensive merger in a terminally declining industry designed to sack staff, with no premium given to shareholders for a minority stake in the resulting business?

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Anyway, here's Citi.

BE11:15am

BE11:15am

And RBC.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

While the deal is highly defensive for both parties, it nonetheless makes sense because of its complementary nature and potential for earnings accretion: (i) both companies are experiencing net outflows, (ii) Standard Life’s balance sheet strength offsets Aberdeen’s balance sheet weakness, and (iii) scale is key as active asset managers combat increased regulatory pressure on performance, required regulatory capital and compliance costs, while also combatting revenue margin weakness (thus, one way to grow is to reduce costs, a strategy that both companies are embracing). However, we expect some AUM attrition in the short term as consultants are usually reluctant to push funds from companies that are merging due to likely dislocation among investment staff (and the possibility for performance issues).

BE11:16am

Despite the defensiveness of the merger, because of the significant level of earnings accretion, we expect ongoing positive momentum in Aberdeen’s share price, and further believe that the combined company will be an attractive investment for income funds. Aberdeen trades at 15.1x FY17 EPS and 14.2x FY18 EPS. Aberdeen yields 6.5% our FY17 dividend forecast.

BE11:16am

And UBS.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Given the size of the deal we would expect client attrition of 3-5%, inline with other deals of this size where there is geographical overlap, combined with the negative impact the merger may have on client flows over the coming 12 months as many funds are put on consultant & discretionary fund manager watchlists until the merger is successfully completed. We estimate this would lower the EPS accretion for shareholders to 6-12%, depending on the scale of client attrition.
The strategic merits are clear - the UK's largest asset manager with £660bn of AUMs benefiting from enhanced scale, global distribution and manufacturing capability. However, ADN has suffered 15 consecutive quarters of outflows and outflows in all 6 of its asset classes in the past 3 quarters. Meanwhile, SL has outflows from its flagship GARS fund driven by performance weakness. While the merger will target "significant synergy potentials", these two institutions must turn their franchises around for shareholders to truly benefit from a potential combination. Given the negative momentum both firms have faced, this will be the true challenge.

BE11:17am

There is some more positive stuff around. There are some analysts who think their sector isn't dying.

BE11:17am

Liberum, for instance.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Brand and scale are all important. If this merger is successful, we would see it as a spring board, from a position of enhanced strength, to embark on further deals, possibly US.
Given the circumstances, we think this is a very shrewd move by ADN and is sensible for SL/. We increase our TP by 27% to 332p, in-line with top-end EPS accretion and DPS.

BE11:17am

But here's the thing ....

BE11:17am

Gilbert spent a lot of time -- as in, more than a year, telling folk he wanted US distribution ....

11:17 am
BE11:17am

You'll remember him talking perhaps a little enviously about how shrewd Henderson was to jump in with Janus

PM11:17am

I do

BE11:17am

So .... how does this deal get him any closer to that ambition?

11:17 am
PM11:18am

It doesnt

BE11:18am

Scale? Nah.

BE11:18am

When's scale ever been a positive for a fund manager? It's usually a negative.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

It certainly was for Standard Life, whose GARS fund grew unwieldy after success in 2009 and 2010.

PM11:18am

The brand argument does hold some weight, surely.

BE11:18am

Both GARS and Aberdeen's key funds have been underperforming benchmarks quite badly, tho.

11:18 am
PM11:19am

hmm

BE11:19am

Back in 2013 it looked like Euan Munro figured he can't deliver much alpha when he was pushing around £17bn, so he chucked it.

PM11:19am

Euan Munro of Aviva

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Brand is useful if you make people money. But the thing with fund management is that your customers can leave very very quickly.

BE11:20am

And once they do, you'll need another three years of outperformance on paper to tempt them back.

BE11:21am

So ........... what about the US? I guess Aberdeen's bijou office is quite close to Trump's golf course, but that hasn't helped any yet.

11:21 am
PM11:21am

hehe

BE11:21am

It looks a lot like Aberdeen has taken the last deal available to it rather than the first, and is trying to dress it up as strategic rather than defensive.

PM11:22am

Played a hard bargain tho

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Ah, nuts, perhaps I'm being over critical. Have another bull.

BE11:22am

Numis.

BE11:23am

In our view, the key attractions of this deal for shareholders, are 1) it will increase diversification of the business, including reducing earning reliance on EM Equities (ADN) and GARS (SL). 2) With a pro-forma £660bn AuM, it will substantially increase the scale of the business to become an industry top 20 player. Scale is a feature we have talked about in the past as becoming increasingly important in the industry, as active managers in our view will increasingly need industrial scale to compete more effectively on price (given the growth of passive and other headwinds). 3) The statement highlights “material earnings accretion” driven by “significant synergy potential.” Whilst this is the final of 7 points outlined in the statement, in the short term at least, we feel it is the one the market will be most focused on. In our view, there is likely to be considerable overlap in back/middle office administration and infrastructure/technology, some overlap in distribution and property footprint, and possible overlap in certain front office activities (most likely in our view: Fixed Income and Multi-Asset given greater similarity of product, less so in Equities given ADN’s significant EM/Asia focus). We would understand the term “significant” synergies to imply c.10% of potential joint cost savings and “material” earnings accretion to imply c.20%+.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Given the limited information available at present, our initial reaction is to increase our target price from 260p to 345p, reflecting the statement implied c.20% + earnings accretion (345p is +c.20% vs. last price), which is where we expect the market's initial focus to be. We expect this to change as more information emerges.

BE11:25am

Numis also talking about potential for a counter, though the note was written before this morning's confirmation. I'll chuck up the names anyway ......

PM11:25am

(Mouselet -- IP2IPO )

11:25 am
BE11:25am

In our 20/06/16 note “Who could buy Aberdeen and how much
could they pay?”, we noted that there could be a number of parties potentially interested in Aberdeen for the cost synergy potential and/or for those currently lacking a leading EM/Asia franchise. We highlighted Blackrock, JP Morgan, Capital, PIMCO, Amundi, Natixis, Invesco, T.Rowe, Legg Mason, AMG, Sumitomo Mitsui, Ameriprise, AllianceBernstein, Standard Life, Prudential, Credit Suisse, Mitsubishi, Macquarie and Aviva as those who are the most likely to have possible interest (there could be others in our view). We suggested at that time that the takeout value could be around 380p (caveat: we have not updated the analysis behind this valuation for developments since then, but feel it is still a reasonable estimate)

BE11:26am

This is the third recent large deal in the industry after Henderson/Janus and Amundi/Pioneer. As we have highlighted in past notes, such as “Predators and Prey” 10/06/16 and “The active asset management industry is changing” 05/01/17, we believe there is scope for further consolidation activity in the active asset management industry, driven by industry headwinds of low expected future investment returns, low organic growth, revenue margin pressure and cost pressures, as well as company specific attractions.

BE11:26am

Sector wise .....

11:26 am
Man Group PLC (EMG:LSE): Last: 146.90, up 5.4 (+3.82%), High: 148.10, Low: 141.30, Volume: 2.93m
BE11:26am

(A cautionary tale on the merits of diversification, one could argue.)

Ashmore Group PLC (ASHM:LSE): Last: 369.00, up 9.1 (+2.53%), High: 379.70, Low: 361.50, Volume: 1.02m
11:26 am
Jupiter Fund Management PLC (JUP:LSE): Last: 431.60, up 8.6 (+2.03%), High: 445.00, Low: 428.90, Volume: 1.31m
BE11:27am

And that'll do.

PM11:27am

Well thanks for all that comprehensive coverage Bryce.

11:26 am
undefined
PM11:27am

Blimey -- already almsot half 11

PM11:27am

Request for Acacia on the right

11:27 am
PM11:27am

Have some Credit Suisse to hand

PM11:28am

But they are off side today's price move

PM11:28am

Political risks and single country exposure to
the fore

11:28 am
PM11:28am

Action: The Ministry of Energy and Minerals in Tanzania has announced a ban on exports of gold/copper concentrate with immediate effect. All of Acacia’s assets are based in Tanzania and in 2016 30% of group revenue was accounted for by gold/copper concentrate exports. Operations are at the moment continuing to produce as normal with the company stockpiling concentrate material while it awaits further information clarification on the ban. We expect an update from the company early next week.

PM11:28am

Potential outcomes: The government has sighted its intention is to bring beneficiation of concentrate back in country similar to moves we have seen in other countries (e.g. Nickel in Indonesia). However, the Tanzanian mining industry is very small with Acacia making up over 50% of national gold production meaning beneficiation hopes may be misplaced (requires scale, in country expertise etc.). The government may be seeking assurances/guarantees over future investments in Tanzania and we can't rule out changes to fiscal/tax/ownership terms. Acacia owns 100% of each of the assets in Tanzania.

PM11:00am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:28 am
Acacia Mining PLC (ACA:LSE): Last: 428.00, down 33 (-7.16%), High: 449.00, Low: 416.20, Volume: 1.09m
PM11:28am

Statement here http://www.investe...170303142407PED62/

BE11:29am

There are all sorts of uncertainties here, not touched on by the CS note.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

For starters, how are the takeover talks going?

PM11:29am

Oh i forgot!

BE11:30am

I mean, it can't be terribly handy to have 30% of your revenues cut off without warning when trying to negotiate a takeover

11:30 am
BE11:30am

...... which Acacia has been trying to engineer for .............. oh, forever.

BE11:30am

Let me get some Jefferies.

BE11:31am

They take it off the buy list.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

While the direct impact is clear, it is more than just greater uncertainty driving today's downgrade. Our past investment case and bullish view on the shares rested on several factors including growing FCF, higher shareholder returns, strengthened in-country relations and catalysts for a lowering of the ABX stake. All of which have now been negatively impacted, making the argument for a valuation re-rating much harder to justify.

BE11:31am

The mid-January announcement of preliminary discussions with Endeavour Mining was a positive for the shares that, along with solid Q4 results, drove more than 20% outperformance vs UK peers through closing on Thursday. In our opinion, with a spike in jurisdictional risk in Tanzania, merger discussions with Endeavour are at the very least going to be delayed. This removes a key catalyst that was likely to have lowered ABX's stake and improve free float and liquidity.

BE11:31am

At this point, we have cut 2017 estimates significantly to reflect the impacted volumes. EBITDA is reduced by 28% and stockpiled material drives working capital higher, weighing on FCF. Previous forecasts for high single-digit FCF yield in 2017 are now breakeven and the net cash balance shrinks by $14m YoY. We do believe the likely outcome is that ACA will be able to resume exporting but expect negotiations to be protracted.

11:32 am
PM11:32am

Endeavour is Toronto listed right?

PM11:32am

And based in Paris

PM11:32am

And wants to move here

11:32 am
PM11:32am

Hmm

undefined
BE11:33am

Back to financials M&A then.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

Seem to remember several brokers saying "avoid financials" in their 2017 M&A baskets. On admittedly very little evidence so far, that seems pretty terrible advice.

BE11:34am

Shawbrook's take-private leaked on Friday.

Shawbrook Group PLC (SHAW:LSE): Last: 319.98, up 3.48 (+1.10%), High: 323.00, Low: 316.00, Volume: 1.29m
11:35 am
BE11:35am

And they put out a statement! Without waiting for the speculation to swirl around the market and drift into the press for numerous days! Interesting approach. Somewhat in contrast to Aberdeen's .....

PM11:36am

ha

BE11:36am

.... Anyway, this is Pollen Street buying back just two years after the float.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

330p plus divi.

BE11:36am

Positive readthrough.

BE11:36am

Here's Credit Suisse.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

Potential 'ripple effect' on specialist lenders' valuations – Aldermore (N, TP 210p) and OSB (OP, TP 370p) both have large PE investors. One caveat is Shawbrook's share price performance had lagged peers – e.g. its shares (prior to news of the possible offer) were the only ones trading lower (c8%) than the IPO price among CS-covered SMID lenders (Figure 1). The read could be more limited for CYB (OP, TP AUD5.25) and VM (N, TP 335p), which don't have large PE investors and are also about double the market cap.

BE11:37am

The Sabadell-TSB precedent – we compared the short-term share price performances of OSB and VM around Sabadell's announcement of a TSB-takeover offer in 12 March 2015 (please see Figure 3 in the note; other SMID lenders didn't have a meaningful trading history to be included). Interestingly, we find that OSB actually outperformed the FTSE250 more strongly after the event (8% on average in the 1 month period after, vs -2% before), than before it. VM's performance was broadly unchanged (14% vs 12%). This is after adjusting for the 1-day price effect of FY results for both banks.

BE11:38am

And Liberum, which is going for a bump.

11:38 am
BE11:39am

The 330p bid per share values Shawbrook, on our forecasts, at 9.5x 2017E EPS and 1.6x price to
forward book value. These multiples are in line with the current average trading multiples of the
specialist banks peer group. We expect Shawbrook to generate ROEs of 18.7% and 17.2% in 2017E
and 2018E respectively. The peer group has traded historically (since Shawbrook’s listing in April
2015) at an average multiple of 9.2x 12 months forward earnings.
We find it intriguing that Pollen Street Capital, which has a 38.9% stake in the business, is bidding to
take the company private less than 2 years after floating the business. The current offer represents a
13.8% premium to the IPO price of 290p. Pollen Street conducted a placing of 25 million shares on
12-Nov-15 at a price of 335p per share (a 1.5% premium to the bid price) and sold a further 13.8
million shares on 25-May-16 to an institutional investor at an undisclosed price.

BE11:39am

We question whether the bid will be successful at the 330p, given that it is only a 14% premium to our
290p price target. We would expect the starting level for a successful bid to be at least 350p, which is
10x our 2017E EPS forecast.

BE11:39am

We believe Friday’s announcement should intensify bid speculation across the peer group,
particularly for the two other recently listed specialist banks – Aldermore (ALD LN) and OneSavings
Bank (OSB LN) – which in our view should be supportive for valuations. Similarly to Shawbrook, both
Aldermore and OneSavings Bank continue to have large private equity holders. Anacap Financial
Partners owns 40% of Aldermore and JC Flowers owns 54% of OneSavings Bank.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Shawbrook results tomorrow.

undefined
PM11:39am

Rabble going on about ITV

11:39 am
PM11:39am

Isn't this just about this court victory tho?

PM11:39am

TVCatchup.com

BE11:39am

Nope.

11:39 am
PM11:39am

Ah

BE11:40am

Popped from 205p to 215p or thereabouts as 11.35. Calmed down now .....

BE11:40am

.... I'm arking around but have yet to hear a specific story.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

And rather than spread baseless speculation that's been made up to try and explain the move, we'll come back to it.

BE11:41am

Live price is up 4%. 211p.

BE11:42am

There is the retransmission stuff, but that looked broadly in the price already.

11:42 am
PM11:42am

I don't quite understand how they can look to charge Virgin £1 per subscriber for ITV1

PM11:42am

If something's free to air, surely it's free to air for everyone

BE11:43am

I can see the logic. Medium is the message and all that.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Have some Liberum, which is a buyer of ITV at every opportunity.

PM11:44am

Sure is

BE11:44am

ITV's court victory could help as a precedent in future retransmission negotiations with Virgin Media. At the moment Virgin Media is benefiting from a copyright exemption under UK law but this exemption is due to be repealed under the new Digital Economy Bill. Once Section 73 has been repealed we expect ITV to enter into commercial agreements which should allow ITV to charge retransmission fees to Virgin Media.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

In terms of what is the upside potential, in our notes on retransmission fees, our view is that a £1 per month per subscriber fee has been suggested as a sensible fee for the price of ITV1. We estimate that there are c. 13m pay-tv subscribers in the UK, with probably less than 10% in the STV regions. If ITV charged Virgin Media £1 per month, this would mean an extra c. £40m+ revenues at 100% margin (on a base of c. 3m subs), equivalent to a c. 4%+ earnings boost. However, assuming ITV could charge Sky at the same rate, we estimate the uplift would be more like c. £140m, or c. 17%. Importantly, these revenues would attract a higher multiple given their subscription element.

BE11:44am

(@AL: see my earlier comment about baseless speculation.)

undefined
11:45 am
BE11:45am

While on TV companies, even though it's not a TV company .....

BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 334.15, up 1.2 (+0.36%), High: 335.35, Low: 332.76, Volume: 2.92m
BE11:46am

Regained UEFA rights to end-20/21.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Price up 32% to £394m.

BE11:46am

Why? I've no idea.

PM11:46am

Nuts

11:46 am
PM11:47am

And they can't provide fibre in inner london zones like Greenwich

BE11:47am

Is this because management is bored of running a utility and fighting with Ofcom and pension fund trustees, and would rather be going to Cannes every May?

BE11:47am

Clearly not.

11:47 am
PM11:48am

The stock is still way below January's warning

PM11:48am

380 or thereabouts previously

BE11:48am

There are a couple of interesting things at the margin. No sub-licensing of games, for instance.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Some waffle about social media

BE11:49am

(@AL: no need for apologies. Just explaining why it hadn't reached this side of the page.)

BE11:49am

.... you'll note Sky's new policy of giving blipvert highlights of live games via Twitter ..... I'm yet to understand the commercial justification for that ......

11:50 am
BE11:50am

..... some bumwash about brand awareness and engaging millennials probably.

PM11:50am

bumwash

BE11:50am

I'd used "tosh" earlier. I needed a synonym.

11:50 am
PM11:51am

Did we agree that "bumwash" is ok for this family show?

BE11:51am

I've made that decision unilaterally. Complaints to the usual places.

BE11:51am

Have some Jefferies, which goes all game theory.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

In a 23 Jan note, we highlighted how UEFA predicted that its rights would raise EUR3.2bn worldwide this time, up 30% on last time. We believe that auction structure was designed to maximise proceeds (rather than audience), evident in the lack of a FTA requirement and the lack of a 'no single bidder' clause. This would suggest that there may have been provision for multiple rounds of bidding. The speed with which today's auction result has followed the start-of-March deadline for tender submissions would suggest that BT faced limited opposition from Sky (or anyone else), and that bidding did not go to multiple rounds. BT shareholders might, therefore, question how necessary it was for their company to meet UEFA's price expectations in full. Moreover, we wonder what this implies for BT's negotiating leverage in future UEFA rights auctions.

BE11:51am

Prior to the June 2013 launch of BT Sport, BT was losing c.200k consumer lines/quarter and Sky was adding BB subs at a similar rate. The immediate impact of BT Sport was to reduce line loss by two-thirds. Adding Champions League to the BT Sport line-up in Sep 2015 has coincided with further erosion in BT line loss and the marginalisation of Sky as a force in the UK BB market. Loss of CL rights would not only have undermined BT's retention efforts, we believe pricing power would also have been significantly impaired. BT Sport Europe has been a core mechanism for BT Consumer to implement above-inflation price rises of escalating frequency. Its importance was reinforced by retail price controls on BT landline-only customers proposed by Ofcom last week. In a 28 Feb note, we outlined how the proposed £5-7 line rental cut for this cohort could impair EBITDA by £115-160m from FY18/19 whilst proposed ongoing index-linked retail price caps could create a recurring annual EBITDA headwind of c.£30m relative to current forecasts.

BE11:51am

Overhangs remain, notably on regulation and lack of visibility on FCF growth post Mar18. (1) Regulatory status quo appears untenable with BT objectives now decoupled from UK policy priorities. Whilst cons now accommodates BT delivering 10Mbps+ BB to the 'last 5%', addressing the digital divide requires extending ultrafast well into the 60% of homes that BT's plans don't currently address. (2) Post-warning, BT’s guidance for norm. FCF in FY17/18 stands in-line with the £3.1bn reported in FY15/16 (when EE was only consolidated for 2 months). BT has yet to present a roadmap that shows investors how FCF post-Mar18 can be restored to pre-warning levels (old FY17/18 norm. FCF guidance was c.£3.6bn). This remains a crucial impediment to any convincing bull case since, without FCF growth post-Mar18, BT does not look capable of sustaining DPS growth. Attempts to construct a recovery scenario are impaired by the fact that one-third of legacy OpFCF derives from ‘black box’ enterprise divisions (GS and BPS).

11:51 am
undefined
PM11:52am

(Nestor Makhno -- do refresh. If problem persists screenshot and email me paul.murphy@ft.com )

BE11:53am

ITV now up just 2.8%. Nothing anywhere to share.

11:53 am
PM11:53am

Drifting back

BE11:54am

Any macro that might carry us through to midday?

PM11:54am

Sure

11:54 am
PM11:54am

It's one of those UBS Q&As that you love

PM11:54am

Is the debt super-cycle finally over?

PM11:55am

Q: How much progress has been made in unwinding the leverage built up prior to the global financial crisis? It depends how you slice and dice the debt. If you look at it from a global level, then debt of the combined household, corporate, government and financial sectors has gone up since 2008, both in nominal terms and in percent of global GDP. However, if you strip out China and the build-up of government debt—which increased in part because governments attempted to provide countercyclical breathing space for private sector balance sheets to adjust—global debt declined by 15% of global GDP. You could also do a straight EM vs DM comparison. The combined debts of all sectors inched up 1% of DM GDP post 2008 compared to a pre-crisis ('02-'08) increase of 56%. But private DM debt has declined by 34% of DM GDP compared to a pre-crisis build-up of 52% of GDP. The EM data is a bit too patchy to do a similar pre/post comparison that far back, but after 2008, total EM debt increased by nearly 100% of GDP (again mostly due to China).

11:54 am
PM11:55am

Q: Where has the greatest deleveraging taken place? Clearly in the financial sector in developed markets. Collectively, banks in developed markets have reduced the sum of their non-deposit funding by 31% of GDP post 2008 after having increased those debts by 33% of GDP between 2002 and 2008. We define bank debt as the sum of all external, wholesale (loans and debt securities) and interbank funding. The Eurozone is the last major banking area to still be deleveraging but it has now fully reversed the entire increase in leverage that took place between 2000 and 2008. The geographical distribution of that deleveraging varies, however. At an aggregate Eurozone level, French banks contributed most to the pre-crisis accumulation of bank debt and Germany has contributed most to the reduction of that debt since then. There are stark differences across Europe (e.g. Belgium cutting three times as much debt as a percent of its own GDP post-crisis as it accumulated pre-crisis) which partly reflect the degree of difficulty banks got into because of problems on the asset side of their balance sheet.

PM11:55am

Q: Why does the amount of debt matter? One of the prevailing theories for the length of post- crisis recovery (the debt super-cycle theory) is that the interconnectedness of problems in the housing sector with banks, corporate and household balance sheets would take a long time to resolve, but that growth could resume once said balance sheets had been restored to good health. Frustration with the slow recovery and a seeming lack of deleveraging by the non-financial sector gave way to alternate theories for lacklustre growth (e.g. secular stagnation). However, the evolution of DM balance sheets looks pretty text-book to us. An end to financial sector deleveraging could lay the groundwork for a recovery in a DM capex cycle. Banking systems that finished the bulk of their deleveraging several years ago (e.g. US, Australia) are already posting much healthier credit growth rates.
